ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A very in-depth understanding of the historical groundings that influence medical device development and their intersections with society (sex, gender, race, class, etc).

how to engage with historians' takes, ways to think about how health and society are related, writing history research papers, thinking about big themes and using them to guide discussions about specific topics
I learned a lot about a wide array of medical technologies (both historical and contemporary) and developed new ways of thinking about how I engage with medicine, tech, and medical institutions.

This class required lots of deep analytical thinking that I really enjoyed. The conversations in class were meaningful, and I was really able to think about complex issues through an analysis of medical history.

It really opened my view on what could be considered a "technology" in medicine. This class makes you think a lot about how we engage with medical technologies, and how technologies have shaped our medical field. Kelly designed the class to be a very fun and interesting approach to a topic that had the potential to be very technical and dry.
I learned how to conceptualize of a medical technology and how to read and digest historical medical text.
I learned how to actively engage with the readings during class.
Critical thinking surrounding history, social class dynamics, the scientific method, and microanalysis

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor O'Donnell is incredibly encouraging of her students and creates a warm environment for students to share their thoughts and ideas. I wouldn't suggest many improvements beyond maybe highlighting some bigger name technologies.

i very much enjoyed this course - it was fun to go to class and i enjoyed completing the readings. i found the requirement that the reading responses be in the form of questions to be a little more difficult than simply submitting a normal reading response. i think it was sometimes hard to engage everyone in the conversations - im not sure how to solve this, but i think just more conversation would improve the course. i liked the mix of activities we did during class time though - it definitely made class more enjoyable as the range of activities was more diverse

I really liked the reading list for the course and appreciated the weekly reflections (I think it helped me - and everyone - engage more with the week's materials and be prepared for class discussion). I also loved the paper prompts.

Weaknesses - None 

Strengths - Seminars were extremely engaging (often very funny too), the readings were the perfect balance of interesting without being too much, and the topic was different every week

the strengths of thsi course were the readings and the professor, there are no weaknesses that come to mind, but I think some of the readings could be rearranged to help with how students conceptualize medical technology, particularly moving the ones from the last weak nearer to the beginning

I loved how the course was structured to explore a new medical technology each week because it kept the course really engaging. I also loved how we were able to Zoom with some of the authors of books that we read.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! Take this course. Professor O'Donnell is lovely and the course content is so interesting. You get to hear about so many different technologies and even meet with some of the authors of the readings you do for the course.

I would definitely recommend this course - there are two papers, one shorter and one longer, which is a big load for the times that they are due, but other than that, it is definitely a fun course. I even enjoyed writing the papers, since they were topics that I was interested in and got to delve deeply into. If you are interested in medicine, society, and history, I would definitely recommend this course. Professor O'Donnell is wonderful and very kind and knowledgable in guiding discussion. She was very thoughtful in the readings she chose and the topics covered and I very much enjoyed the class.
Yes, I would - anyone interested in med technologies (or the field of medicine more generally).
Yes! Professor O'Donnell is great and this class will really get you thinking! The readings are really interesting and the trip to the Med School library was fun.

Yes! Professor O'Donnell is a very personable professor and made the seminar discussions feel less like class and more like a book club (but based on articles and personal experiences rather than on books). It is a very relevant topic that I think all students should learn more about, and the workload was very low while it still incited engagement at the same time.
Yes
Yes, great course that really expands and challenges your perception of medical technology
Yes, the class discussions were very interesting.
Yes!
